title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: outlines propose change glyenzy. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("glycoverse/glyenzy", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to glyenzy
text: Please note glyenzy project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

what: Your First Taste of Glycan Engineering 🚀
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: Let’s dive right hands-example! ’ll start charming O-glycan ’s perfect demonstration:  Notice glycosidic bond labeled responsible enzyme? ’s beauty glycan biosynthesis – every connection story! (’ll skip rightmost peptide bond now.) ’s star glycan IUPAC-condensed notation: Time meet new best friend: get_involved_enzymes() 👋 clever function reveals enzymes might hand building glycan: Cool, right? spot enzymes diagram, also whispers B4GALT1/2/3/4 potentially involved. (Don’t worry, ’ll unpack mystery soon!) wait, ’s ! want see happens add new enzyme mix? Let’s give ST3GAL2 chance work magic: Fascinating! 🎯 function returns glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector, real story happened: shiny new sialic acid got attached β1-3 Gal, β1-4 Gal completely ignored. ? ST3GAL2 incredibly picky – recognizes “Gal(β1-3)GalNAc(α1-” substrate. Getting hang ? Great! Let’s explore else glyenzy can .
code: glycan <- "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-6)[Gal(b1-3)]GalNAc(a1-" get_involved_enzymes(glycan) #> [1] "B4GALT1" "B4GALT2" "B4GALT3" "B4GALT4" "B4GALT5" "C1GALT1" "GCNT1"   #> [8] "GCNT3"   "GCNT4" apply_enzyme(glycan, "ST3GAL2") #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-6)]GalNAc(a1- #> # Unique structures: 1

title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: Ever wondered glycan’s backstory? glyenzy molecular detective, ready solve three key mysteries: ? glycosyltransferases glycoside hydrolases involved? many times? often enzyme swing action? ’s timeline? order biochemical events unfold? Behind scenes, glyenzy catalogued reaction rules 62 enzymes molecular database. Want peek enzyme’s profile? Just use enzyme("MGAT3") prepare amazed biochemical details! Combined sophisticated motif-matching algorithms glymotif, can reconstruct glycan’s complete biography. ’ve already met get_involved_enzymes() – perfect getting full cast characters. sometimes want targeted intel: is_synthesized_by() answers “enzyme X involved?” simple yes/count_enzyme_steps() tells exactly many times enzyme got busy intel gold multiomics analysis – imagine linking glycan structures directly enzyme expression levels! 📊 Ready grand finale? Meet rebuild_biosynthesis() – function reconstructs glycan’s complete life story: get back directed igraph object – think molecular family tree! 🌳 vertex represents glycan structure, edge represents enzymatic step. one enzyme involved enzymatic step, multiple edges created two vertices. Let’s try complex N-glycan:  Note: plotting use TLC – ’re working prettier visualizations! 🎨
code: path <- rebuild_biosynthesis(glycan) path #> IGRAPH c7fa693 DN-- 4 9 --  #> + attr: name (v/c), enzyme (e/c), step (e/n) #> + edges from c7fa693 (vertex names): #> [1] GalNAc(a1-                       ->Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-                        #> [2] Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-              ->Gal(b1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-6)]GalNAc(a1-          #> [3] Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-              ->Gal(b1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-6)]GalNAc(a1-          #> [4] Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-              ->Gal(b1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-6)]GalNAc(a1-          #> [5] Gal(b1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-6)]GalNAc(a1-->Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-6)[Gal(b1-3)]GalNAc(a1- #> [6] Gal(b1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-6)]GalNAc(a1-->Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-6)[Gal(b1-3)]GalNAc(a1- #> [7] Gal(b1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-6)]GalNAc(a1-->Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-6)[Gal(b1-3)]GalNAc(a1- #> + ... omitted several edges glycan <- "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" path <- rebuild_biosynthesis(glycan) plot(   path,   layout = layout_as_tree(path),   vertex.label = NA,   vertex.size = 10,   edge.arrow.size = 0.3,   margin = 0 )

what: Crystal Ball Mode: Predicting Glycan Futures 🔮
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: Now really fun part – playing molecular fortune teller! glyenzy can predict new glycans emerge mix specific enzymes existing structures. Let’s start simple work way serious biochemical wizardry. happens introduce C1GALT1 lonely GalNAc? Boom! 💥 just witnessed birth famous Core 1 O-GalNAc glycan! ’s apply_enzyme() works: give glycan enzyme, returns possible products. multiple outcomes possible, ’ll get bundled glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector. Perfect! antennae can galactosylated, giving us two distinct products. biochemical branching action! 🌿
code: # The humble GalNAc core of O-glycan glycan <- "GalNAc(a1-" apply_enzyme(glycan, "C1GALT1") #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1- #> # Unique structures: 1 # A bi-antennary agalactosylated N-glycan (fancy name for "no galactose yet") glycan <- "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" apply_enzyme(glycan, "B4GALT1") #> <glycan_structure[2]> #> [1] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [2] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 2

previous_headings: Crystal Ball Mode: Predicting Glycan Futures 🔮
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: Ready serious fun? Let’s create molecular primordial soup! Toss glycan substrates, add cocktail enzymes, watch magic unfold multiple reaction steps. Use spawn_glycans() full experience, spawn_glycans_step() prefer watch drama unfold step step: party! 🎉 ’s enzyme brought table: B4GALT1: Adds β1-4 Gal lonely GlcNAc branches ST3GAL3: Decorates α2-3 sialic acid (fancy finishing touch) MGAT3: Drops bisecting GlcNAc right core mannose result? spectacular collection 32 different glycans, including original starting structure!
code: # Our trusty bi-antennary N-glycan meets three enzyme friends spawn_glycans(glycan, c("B4GALT1", "ST3GAL3", "MGAT3")) #> <glycan_structure[32]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [2] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [3] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [4] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [5] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [6] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [7] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [8] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)][Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [9] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [10] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> ... (22 more not shown) #> # Unique structures: 32

title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: go wild glyenzy, important caveats keep mind:

previous_headings: The Fine Print: What You Need to Know ⚠️
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: glyenzy currently human-centric package, focusing specifically N-glycans O-GalNAc glycans. ’re working GAGs, glycolipids, glycans plants insects, results might accurate. ’re basically specialists, generalists! 🎯

previous_headings: The Fine Print: What You Need to Know ⚠️
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: algorithms intentionally inclusive – assume possible isoenzymes capable catalyzing reaction might involved. means interpret results grain salt. instance, glyenzy spots motif “Neu5Ac(α2-3)Gal(β1-”, ’ll flag ST3GAL3 ST3GAL4 potential culprits. reality, tissue specificity factors might mean one actually active. Think getting list suspects rather definitive perpetrator! 🕵️

previous_headings: The Fine Print: What You Need to Know ⚠️
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: glyenzy picky precision – works concrete residues like “Glc” “GalNAc”, generic ones like “Hex” “HexNAc”. data uses generic terms, ’ll need specific! 🎯

previous_headings: The Fine Print: What You Need to Know ⚠️
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: Modifications like sulfation phosphorylation aren’t supported yet, might actually break algorithms. glycans decorated extras, use glyrepr::remove_substituents() get clean, analysis-ready structures.

previous_headings: The Fine Print: What You Need to Know ⚠️
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: Incomplete partially degraded glycan structures can lead glyenzy astray. Make sure input represents full, intact glycan reliable results! ✅

previous_headings: The Fine Print: What You Need to Know ⚠️
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: glyenzy specific starting points biosynthetic narratives: N-glycans: Begin Glc₃Man₉GlcNAc₂ precursor (post-OST transfer) O-glycans: Start GalNAc(α1- (post-GALNT addition) means don’t track earlier steps – ALGs building N-glycan precursor, OST transferring asparagine, GALNTs adding initial GalNAc. pick story ! 📖

what: Behind the Scenes: The Technical Magic ⚙️
title: Get Started with glyenzy
text: Curious makes glyenzy tick? ’s tech stack: glyrepr: foundation representing glycan structures glyparse: linguistic expert decodes IUPAC-condensed notation glymotif: pattern-matching wizard finds structural motifs enzymes live enzyme() objects (technically glyenzy_enzyme S3 class instances). Want peek hood enzyme? Just call enzyme("YOUR_FAVORITE_ENZYME") prepare detailed biochemical profile! 🔬

title: Authors and Citation
text: Bin Fu. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Fu B (2025). glyenzy: Deconstruction Glycosylation Biosynthesis. R package version 0.2.0, https://glycoverse.github.io/glyenzy/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {glyenzy: Deconstruction Glycosylation Biosynthesis},   author = {Bin Fu},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.2.0},   url = {https://glycoverse.github.io/glyenzy/}, }

title: Deconstruction Glycosylation Biosynthesis
text: glyenzy package helps simulate biosynthetic process glycosylation silico. Key features include: identifying specific glycosyltransferase responsible glycosidic bond; reconstructing biosynthetic pathway given glycan; exploring possible transformations two glycan structures via glycosyltransferases glycosidases; predicting glycans can synthesized given substrate structure set enzymes.

title: Deconstruction Glycosylation Biosynthesis
text: can install latest release glyenzy GitHub : install development version:
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("glycoverse/glyenzy@*release") pak::pak("glycoverse/glyenzy")

title: Deconstruction Glycosylation Biosynthesis
text: Say glycan… want know enzymes participates biosynthesis glycan… go! ’re curious new glycans can generated applying ST3GAL2?
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyenzy) glycan <- "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-6)[Gal(b1-3)]GalNAc(a1-" get_involved_enzymes(glycan) #> [1] "B4GALT1" "B4GALT2" "B4GALT3" "B4GALT4" "B4GALT5" "C1GALT1" "GCNT1"   #> [8] "GCNT3"   "GCNT4" apply_enzyme(glycan, "ST3GAL2") #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-6)]GalNAc(a1- #> # Unique structures: 1

what: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: function simulates action enzyme glycan. returns possible products generated enzyme given glycans.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
code: apply_enzyme(glycans, enzyme, return_list = NULL)

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: glycans glyrepr::glycan_structure(), character vector glycan structure strings supported glyparse::auto_parse(). enzyme enzyme() gene symbol. return_list NULL (default), return list glyrepr::glycan_structure() glycans length greater 1, single glyrepr::glycan_structure() glycans length 1. Set TRUE always return list. can useful working programmatically unknown input length. Note return_list = FALSE length(glycans) > 1, error thrown.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector, list vectors.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: important notes functions glyenzy package.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: algorithms enzyme information glyenzy applicable humans, specifically N-glycans O-GalNAc glycans. Results may inaccurate types glycans (e.g., GAGs, glycolipids) glycans species (e.g., plants, insects).

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: algorithm takes intentionally inclusive approach, assuming possible isoenzymes capable catalyzing given reaction may involved. Therefore, results interpreted caution. example, humans, detection motif "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-" return "ST3GAL3" "ST3GAL4". reality, one might active, depending factors tissue specificity.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: function works glycans containing concrete residues (e.g., "Glc", "GalNAc"), glycans generic residues (e.g., "Hex", "HexNAc").

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: Subtituents (e.g. sulfation, phosphorylation) supported yet, algorithms might fail glycans subtituents. glycans contains substituents, use glyrepr::remove_substituents() get clean glycans.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: glycan structure incomplete partially degraded, result may misleading.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
text: Throughout glyenzy, starting glycan Glc(3)Man(9)GlcNAc(2) precursor N-glycans, GalNAc(a1- O-glycans. means enzymes involved N-glycan precursor biosynthesis, mainly ALGs, OST, transfered precursor Asn, considered . Similarly, GALNTs O-glycans considered.

title: Apply an Enzyme to a Glycan — apply_enzyme
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Use `glycan_structure()` and `enzyme()` glycan <- auto_parse("GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-") apply_enzyme(glycan, enzyme("MGAT3")) #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 1  # Or use characters directly apply_enzyme("GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-", "MGAT3") #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 1  # Vectorized input glycans <- c(   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" ) apply_enzyme(glycans, "MGAT3") #> [[1]] #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 1 #>  #> [[2]] #> <glycan_structure[1]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)][GlcNAc(b1-4)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 1 #>

text: important notes functions glyenzy package.

title: Count Enzyme Steps — count_enzyme_steps
text: algorithms enzyme information glyenzy applicable humans, specifically N-glycans O-GalNAc glycans. Results may inaccurate types glycans (e.g., GAGs, glycolipids) glycans species (e.g., plants, insects).

title: Count Enzyme Steps — count_enzyme_steps
text: algorithm takes intentionally inclusive approach, assuming possible isoenzymes capable catalyzing given reaction may involved. Therefore, results interpreted caution. example, humans, detection motif "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-" return "ST3GAL3" "ST3GAL4". reality, one might active, depending factors tissue specificity.

title: Count Enzyme Steps — count_enzyme_steps
text: function works glycans containing concrete residues (e.g., "Glc", "GalNAc"), glycans generic residues (e.g., "Hex", "HexNAc").

title: Count Enzyme Steps — count_enzyme_steps
text: Subtituents (e.g. sulfation, phosphorylation) supported yet, algorithms might fail glycans subtituents. glycans contains substituents, use glyrepr::remove_substituents() get clean glycans.

title: Count Enzyme Steps — count_enzyme_steps
text: glycan structure incomplete partially degraded, result may misleading.

title: Count Enzyme Steps — count_enzyme_steps
text: Throughout glyenzy, starting glycan Glc(3)Man(9)GlcNAc(2) precursor N-glycans, GalNAc(a1- O-glycans. means enzymes involved N-glycan precursor biosynthesis, mainly ALGs, OST, transfered precursor Asn, considered . Similarly, GALNTs O-glycans considered.

title: Count Enzyme Steps — count_enzyme_steps
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Use `glycan_structure()` and `enzyme()` glycan <- auto_parse("Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-") count_enzyme_steps(glycan, enzyme("ST6GAL1")) #> [1] 1  # Or use characters directly count_enzyme_steps("Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-", "ST6GAL1") #> [1] 1  # Vectorized input glycans <- c(   "Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" ) count_enzyme_steps(glycans, "ST6GAL1") #> [1] 1 0

title: Enzymes — enzyme
text: Glycosylation catalyzed two types enzymes: glycosyltransferases (GTs) glycoside hydrolases (GHs). Glycosyltransferases catalyze transfer sugar residue donor acceptor. Glycoside hydrolases catalyze removal sugar residue substrate. glyenzy provides data structure (glyenzy_enzyme) represent enzymes. Use enzyme() gene symbol load predefined enzyme. example, use enzyme("ST3GAL3") load enzyme ST3GAL3. Throughout package, can use enzyme()s enzyme argument, just use gene symbol directly. example, involve("Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-", "ST3GAL3") involve("Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-", enzyme("ST3GAL3")) equivalent.

title: Enzymes — enzyme
code: enzyme(symbol)

title: Enzymes — enzyme
text: symbol gene symbol enzyme.

title: Enzymes — enzyme
text: glyenzy_enzyme object.

title: Enzymes — enzyme
text: enzyme() list following elements: name: name enzyme, usually gene symbol. rules: list glyenzy_enzyme_rule objects. rule list following fields: acceptor: motif enzyme recognizes acceptor_alignment: alignment acceptor rejects: motifs enzyme reject act rejects_alignment: alignment rejects product: product generated enzyme acceptor_idx: node index acceptor enzyme acts . GTs, node new residue attached . GHs, node removed. product_idx: node index product residue product structure. GTs, index newly added residue product. GHs, NULL (new residue added). new_residue: new residue added enzyme. GHs, NULL. new_linkage: linkage new residue. GHs, NULL. type: type enzyme, "GT" glycosyltransferase "GH" glycoside hydrolase. species: species enzyme, e.g. "human" "mouse". can see information printing enzyme object.

title: Enzymes — enzyme
code: library(glyrepr)  enzyme("ST3GAL3") #>  #> ── Enzyme: ST3GAL3 ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ℹ Type: "GT" (Glycosyltransferase) #> ℹ Species: "human" #>  #> ── Rules (3) ── #>  #> → Rule 1: terminal alignment #> Acceptor: "Gal(b1-3)GlcNAc(b1-" #> Product: "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)GlcNAc(b1-" #> → Rule 2: terminal alignment #> Acceptor: "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" #> Product: "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" #> → Rule 3: terminal alignment #> Acceptor: "Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(b1-" #> Product: "Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(b1-"

what: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
text: Find synthesis path one glycan structure another using enzymatic reactions. function uses breadth-first search find shortest path possible paths within given number steps.

title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
code: find_synthesis_path(from, to, enzymes = NULL, max_steps = 10, filter = NULL)

title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
text: glyrepr::glycan_structure() scalar, character string supported glyparse::auto_parse(). starting glycan structure. glyrepr::glycan_structure() scalar, character string supported glyparse::auto_parse(). target glycan structure. enzymes character vector gene symbols, list enzyme() objects. NULL (default), available enzymes used. max_steps Integer, maximum number enzymatic steps search. Default 10. filter Optional function filter generated glycans step. take glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector input return logical vector length. applied generated glycans BFS step pruning.

title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
text: igraph::igraph() object representing synthesis path(s). Vertices represent glycan structures name attribute containing IUPAC-condensed strings. Edges represent enzymatic reactions enzyme attribute containing gene symbols step attribute indicating step number.

title: Find Synthesis Path Between Glycan Structures — find_synthesis_path
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Find shortest path from <- "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" to <- "Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" path <- find_synthesis_path(from, to, enzymes = "ST6GAL1", max_steps = 3)  # View the path igraph::as_data_frame(path, what = "edges") #>                  from                              to  enzyme step #> 1 Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- ST6GAL1    1

title: Identify Potentially Involved Enzymes — get_involved_enzymes
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Use `glycan_structure()` glycans <- auto_parse(c(   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" )) get_involved_enzymes(glycans) #> [[1]] #> [1] "MOGS"   "GANAB"  "MAN1B1" "MAN1A1" "MAN1A2" "MAN1C1" "MAN2A1" "MAN2A2" #> [9] "MGAT1"  #>  #> [[2]] #>  [1] "MOGS"   "GANAB"  "MAN1B1" "MAN1A1" "MAN1A2" "MAN1C1" "MAN2A1" "MAN2A2" #>  [9] "MGAT1"  "MGAT2"  #>   # Or use characters directly get_involved_enzymes("GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-") #> [1] "MOGS"   "GANAB"  "MAN1B1" "MAN1A1" "MAN1A2" "MAN1C1" "MAN2A1" "MAN2A2" #> [9] "MGAT1"

title: Determine Whether a Glycan Is Synthesized by a Given Enzyme — is_synthesized_by
text: basic approach straightforward: reaction rule associated enzyme, function checks whether corresponding product motif appears glycan. rule matches, function returns TRUE. N-glycans, additional logic applied handle special cases. Products MGAT1 often trimmed glycoside hydrolases, meaning final glycan product may longer contain original motif. cases, function instead looks specific motif markers determine enzyme involvement.

title: Determine Whether a Glycan Is Synthesized by a Given Enzyme — is_synthesized_by
code: library(glyrepr) library(glyparse)  # Use `glycan_structure()` and `enzyme()` glycan <- auto_parse("Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-") is_synthesized_by(glycan, enzyme("ST6GAL1")) #> [1] TRUE  # Or use characters directly is_synthesized_by("Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-", "ST6GAL1") #> [1] TRUE  # Vectorized input glycans <- c(   "Neu5Ac(a2-6)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" ) is_synthesized_by(glycans, "ST6GAL1") #> [1]  TRUE FALSE

what: Rebuild the Biosynthetic Path of Glycans — rebuild_biosynthesis
title: Rebuild the Biosynthetic Path of Glycans — rebuild_biosynthesis
text: Reconstruct biosynthetic pathway one glycans using enzymatic reactions. function uses multi-target breadth-first search find feasible pathways can synthesize target glycans.

title: Rebuild the Biosynthetic Path of Glycans — rebuild_biosynthesis
code: rebuild_biosynthesis(glycans, enzymes = NULL, max_steps = 20, filter = NULL)

title: Rebuild the Biosynthetic Path of Glycans — rebuild_biosynthesis
text: glycans glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector, character vector strings supported glyparse::auto_parse(). Can also single glycan. multiple glycans provided, starting structure decided first glycan. Therefore, please make sure glycans mixed vector N- O-glycans. enzymes character vector gene symbols, list enzyme() objects. NULL (default), available enzymes used. max_steps Integer, maximum number enzymatic steps search. Default 20. filter Optional function filter generated glycans step. take glyrepr::glycan_structure() vector input return logical vector length. applied generated glycans BFS step pruning.

title: Rebuild the Biosynthetic Path of Glycans — rebuild_biosynthesis
text: igraph::igraph() object representing synthesis path(s). Vertices represent glycan structures name attribute containing IUPAC-condensed strings. Edges represent enzymatic reactions enzyme attribute containing gene symbols step attribute indicating step number. multiple targets, graph includes synthesis paths needed reach every target glycan.

title: Rebuild the Biosynthetic Path of Glycans — rebuild_biosynthesis
text: N-glycans, starting structure assumed "Glc(3)Man(9)GlcNAc(2)", N-glycan precursor transfered Asn OST. O-glycans, starting structure assumed "GalNAc(a1-".

what: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
text: function simulates action enzymes glycans. Think like primordial soup put glycans enzymes, let interact generate new glycans. spawn_glycans_step() performs one round enzyme action, spawn_glycans() performs multiple rounds. difference spawn_glycans_step() spawn_glycans(n_steps = 1) latter returns original input glycans well. , vector unique glycan structures returned. number glycans generated spawn_glycans() typically exponential, can quickly become large. Therefore, recommended use small number steps carefully select enzymes. Also, can use filter argument prune results round.

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
code: spawn_glycans_step(glycans, enzymes)  spawn_glycans(glycans, enzymes, n_steps = 5, filter = NULL)

text: Throughout glyenzy, starting glycan Glc(3)Man(9)GlcNAc(2) precursor N-glycans, GalNAc(a1- O-glycans. means enzymes involved N-glycan precursor biosynthesis, mainly ALGs, OST, transfered precursor Asn, considered . Similarly, GALNTs O-glycans considered.

title: Apply Enzymes to Spawn Glycans — spawn_glycans_step
code: # Use `spawn_glycans_step()` to build glycans step by step glycan <- "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" glycan |>   spawn_glycans_step("MGAT2") |>   spawn_glycans_step("B4GALT1") |>   spawn_glycans_step("ST3GAL3") #> <glycan_structure[2]> #> [1] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [2] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 2  # Use `spawn_glycans()` to simulate a primordial soup glycans <- c(   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-",   "GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-" ) enzymes <- c("B4GALT1", "ST3GAL3") spawn_glycans(glycans, enzymes, n_steps = 5) #> <glycan_structure[12]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [2] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [3] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [4] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [5] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [6] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [7] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [8] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [9] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [10] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> ... (2 more not shown) #> # Unique structures: 12  # Use `filter` to prune the results after each round # Here we keep only glycans that are synthesized by MGAT2 spawn_glycans(glycans, enzymes, n_steps = 5, filter = ~ is_synthesized_by(.x, "MGAT2")) #> <glycan_structure[9]> #> [1] GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [2] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [3] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [4] Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [5] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [6] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [7] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [8] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)[Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> [9] Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-3)[Neu5Ac(a2-3)Gal(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-2)Man(a1-6)]Man(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc(b1- #> # Unique structures: 9

title: glyenzy 0.2.0
text: Remove return parameter find_synthesis_path() rebuild_biosynthesis(). Now always return possible paths.

title: glyenzy 0.2.0
text: rebuild_biosynthesis() now supports multiple target glycans. resulting graph contains given target glycans intermediate glycans.

title: glyenzy 0.2.0
text: Update documentations find_synthesis_path() rebuild_biosynthesis() include important notes. Fix bugs find_synthesis_path() rebuild_biosynthesis() glycan structure strings IUPAC-condensed format parsed. Add checks functions ensure input glycans intact linkages substituents, raise errors helpful messages . Refactor apply_enzyme() stop using internal glymotif functions avoid fragile dependency.

title: glyenzy 0.1.1
text: Fix bugs introduced breaking changes glyrepr v0.7.0.

title: glyenzy 0.1.0
text: First release glyenzy!
